Lions 2013 'Ones to Watch': Part One

22/12/2012

With the 2013 Lions series on the horizon, George Barrett makes an early prediction for his starting XV against Australia

Image by

By undefined undefined

It's back. Yes, that's right, the four years of waiting are nearly at an end and the Lions series will kick start in less than six months. After the virtuoso rugby witnessed in 2009, anticipation is high for the 2013 series. With this in mind, here is the first of my possible Lions XVs, which will be updated at the halfway mark of the Six Nations. Front Row 1. Cian Healy (Ire) 2. Rory Best (Ire) 3. Adam Jones (Wal) This is a tough one. With Gethin Jenkins dropped a couple of times by Wales in the Autumn Tests Cian Healy is now my favourite for loose-head prop, whilst Adam Jones takes up tight-head. Both are being challenged by the England props of Alex Corbisiero and Dan Cole after their performances against the Springboks and the All Blacks, but these two remain ahead. Rory Best is my bet for hooker, after Dylan Hartley missed the autumn tests through injury. Second Row 4. Joe Launchbury (Eng) 5. Richie Gray (Sco) After Joe Launchbury's simply stunning autumn series, I am going to be bold here and pick him as a starter. Richie Gray takes up the second row berth, and to me he is a pretty much certain to start. Paul O'Connell has a great reputation and with so much experience I would like to see him in the squad. Courtney Lawes could prove useful if he has a good Six Nations, whilst Alun Wyn Jones also has the street cred despite an injury that has set him back. Back Row 6. Tom Wood (Eng) 7. Sam Warburton (Wal) 8. Toby Faletau (Wal) A few months ago I would have said Sam Warburton had nailed the number 7 jersey and was a good bet for Lions captain, but after the autumn, where his stats show him up to be rather ordinary, I am not so sure. He still gets the spot at open-side (just) but only really based on the fact that Gatland has stated he wants an out-and-out open side. Chris Robshaw was fantastic against the All Blacks and is a solid player in general, whilst Sean O'Brien is also very good, but neither are out-and-out open-sides - remember we are dealing with David Pockock this summer. Tom Wood is a pretty good bet for blind side, but Stephen Ferris and Tom Croft are also a handful and one of those two should fly. Toby Faletau is my pick at number eight. Half-Backs 9. Ben Youngs (Eng) 10. Johnny Sexton (Ire) A couple of months ago I would have said Mike Philips was a good bet for another Lions start at scrum half following a great series in 2009, but after the autumn tests I am going with Ben Youngs, though Danny Care's club form has been exceptional. Both the England number nines look likely to tour. Jonny Sexton has now pretty much nailed on the number 10 shirt and he is just the sort of fly half we need against the Wallabies. He was fantastic against the Pumas in November. Second choice is a harder call, and it depends whether Gatland will want to tour with two or three reserve 10s. Owen Farrell was great against the All Blacks but lacks the all round game of Sexton, whilst Rhys Priestland's recent injury has not done him any favours. Centres 12. Manu Tuilagi (Eng) 13. Brian O'Driscoll (Ire) Whilst he has played 13 for England over the autumn, I would love to see Manu Tuilagi move to inside and team up with Brian O'Driscoll. Yes O'Driscoll is passed his best, is very near the end of his career, and will probably miss the whole of the Six Nations, but the man is a legend and this combination has the potential to be breath-taking. I feel that O'Driscoll could make up for Tuilagi's lack of kicking game as well. Wales' Jonathon Davies is playing well and one can never forget Jamie Roberts, but I would love to see this combo, even if it looks unlikely. Back three 11. Tim Visser (Sco) 14. George North (Wal) 15. Rob Kearney (Ire) It's nip and tuck between Rob Kearney and Leigh Halfpenny for full back. Both have the experience, both have been playing well recently, and both have the potential to cause serious problems to the Aussie defence Down Under. I would be happy to see either of them take the number 15 shirt, and I have only just given it to Kearney. Alex Goode has made a good case to tour, and the fact that he can also cover fly-half strengthens his case. One cannot forget Mike Brown, who only recently had the English full back jersey, whilst Ben Foden on form is fantastic. At wing, George North is a must to start, whilst Tim Visser now takes up the other wing after a good autumn series and Tommy Bowe's untimely injury that means he sadly will miss the whole of the Six Nations. Despite a pretty miserable autumn overall for the home nations, I am quietly confident that 2013 could be a series to remember. Australia at their best are a fantastic team to watch and after the heroic efforts of the 2009 Lions I feel we could be set for three stunning test matches. Although the Wallabies narrowly beat both Wales and England, they are still not playing as well as they could be and if that stays the way it is then I am going to go for a narrow 2-1 series win to the Lions. Roll on the summer.
